links.title: A nanoelectronics-blood-based diagnostic biomarker for myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS)
links.description: Myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS) is a disease which afflicts approximately 2 million people in the United States and many more around the globe. A combination of factors might trigger ME/CFS, and there is currently no well-established blood-based biomarker to diagnose it. Taking advantage of advancements in micro/nanofabrication, direct electrical detection of cellular and molecular properties, microfluidics, and artifi...

links.title: A Meta-Analysis of Oxidative Stress Markers in Depression
links.description: Object Studies have suggested that depression was accompanied by oxidative stress dysregulation, including abnormal total antioxidant capacity (TAC), antioxidants, free radicals, oxidative damage and autoimmune response products. This meta-analysis aims to analyse the clinical data quantitatively by comparing the oxidative stress markers between depressed patients and healthy controls.   Methods A search was conducted to collect the studies that ...

links.title: Redirecting
Redirecting
Dangers of research into chronic fatigue syndrome
links.description:
Nigel Hawkes reports how threats to researchers from activists in the CFS/ME community are stifling research into the condition

There are jobs that carry a risk, such as volunteering as a human cannon ball at a funfair. There are jobs that attract opprobrium and abuse, such as becoming an estate agent, driving a white van, or selling double glazing over the telephone. And then there is the job of trying to conduct research into chronic fatigue s...

links.title: PACE trial - MEpedia
links.description: The study compared standardised specialist medical care (SMC) alone to SMC plus Adaptive Pacing Therapy (APT), Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), or Graded Exercise Therapy (GET). links.title: How Scurvy Was Cured, then the Cure Was Lost

links.title: The Six-fold Nature of Snow
links.description: Some people have asked me why snow crystals have six corners. The answers I’ve seen in books and the Internet are incomplete at best. Here’s a more complete answer. (A pdf copy of this article is here.) How the crystal got its “six” It’s a cold winter’s…

links.title: A Violent Splash of Magma That May Have Made the Moon
links.description: The object thought to have formed our lunar companion may have smashed into a baby Earth still covered in a fiery ocean.

links.title: Moon Rock Analysis Casts Doubt on Lunar Origins
links.description: A new analysis of lunar minerals shows the moon is more similar to the Earth than thought, challenging the prevailing view of our nearest celestial neighbor formed.

links.title: Panspermia - Wikipedia
links.description: Panspermia (from Ancient Greek  πᾶν (pan), meaning 'all', and  σπέρμα (sperma), meaning 'seed') is the hypothesis that life exists throughout the Universe, distributed by space dust,[1] meteoroids,[2] asteroids, comets,[3] planetoids,[4] and also by spacecraft carrying unintended contamination by microorganisms.[5][6][7] Distribution may have occurred between galaxies, and so may not be restricted to the limited scale of solar systems.[8][9]

links.title: Engineers say Boeing pushed to limit safety testing in race to certify planes, including 737 MAX
links.description: Some current and former Boeing engineers who worked on behalf of the FAA say company managers pressured them to limit safety analysis and testing and analysis on planes, including the 737 MAX, in order to meet corporate cost and schedule...
links.original_title: Engineers say Boeing pushed to limit safety testing in race to certify planes

links.title: Metamorphic Testing • Hillel Wayne
links.description: Confession: I read the ACM Magazine. This makes me a dweeb even in programming circles. One of the things I found in it is “Metamorphic Testing”. I’ve never heard of it, and nobody I knew heard about it either. But the academic literature was shockingly impressive: many incredibly successful case studies in wildly different fields. So why haven’t we heard of it before? There’s only one article anywhere targeted at people outside academia.
links.original_title: Metamorphic Testing
